title: Science Weekly: The Hidden Face of Research
author: Ilia Blinderman
header-title__top: Contents lists available at The Pudding
intro: Welcome to The Pudding’s Science Weekly. This is the first of 4 pieces devoted to exploring little-known scientific findings about science. Specifically, the unexpected or underappreciated aspects of how we do science, and its implications.

background.value: But what happens when trust in science erodes? Psychology, my field of study for nearly a decade, is facing just such a crisis. Power poses? Highly questionable. The popular conception ofimplicit bias? Thoroughly href=”https://www.thecut.com/2017/01/psychologys-racism-measuring-tool-isnt-up-to-the-job.html”>suspect. What to do?

First, in addition to supplying a methodology section to every experimental study, we can give researchers access to the relevant raw data to analyze for themselves. But things aren’t quite as simple. I’ll explain why.

part-1.value: In 2013, a group of researchers led by UBC’s Timothy Vine found that the availability of research data declines rapidly with article age*. Say you’re a researcher, and you want to conduct a replication of some analysis that people have been citing for years, because you’ve got a hunch that conclusions aren’t airtight; there’s a 90% likelihood that these data just aren’t around anymore. But what does that really mean, in terms of concrete terms? How much of our work, as scientists, no longer has the data behind it?

part-2.value: The whole thesis relies on the literature review, where I scour the available evidence to set frame my hypothesis about the impact of our psyche on physiological symptoms. Using the probabilities in the paper we first discussed, I’ve color-coded each sentence that included a citation to past research. Dark passages are more likely to have data behind the studies; light ones are likely missing the raw data which led to the findings in the first place.
